awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: Supporting High-Value Analytics on Big Low-Value Data
awd_abstract_narration:
A wealth of digital information is being generated through social networks, blogs, online communities, news sources, and mobile applications as well as a myriad of device-based sources such as smart-home devices and wearable sensors. Data analysts in a number of domains, e.g., government, public health, national security, and public safety, stand to benefit greatly from the ability to perform retrospective as well as interactive analyses over such data. The key feature of this data is that an individual item, such as a tweet or a sensor reading, is low-value by nature. Such data becomes of high-value only when large quantities of such data are analyzed together. This project seeks new data management techniques to enable data analysts to process large quantities of such low-value data. The key challenge is to support analytic queries efficiently and interactively, while being aware of the low-value nature of the data, using cost-effective solutions such as cheap commodity hardware.

Support for data analytics has been well studied, both for centralized and parallel databases, for tabular data. However, given memory prices where the high-value transactional data for a typical enterprise can fit in the memory of a high-end server, most recent work has been on analytics for memory-resident data. In contrast, this project aims to support analytics over data arising from social, mobile, Web, and IoT data sources. This data is much larger, so memory-residence is not cost effective for storage or analysis, as only in aggregate do the data items become high-value. The project has three main thrusts. The first thrust focuses on efficient storage and resource-aware query processing for large volumes of data that are nested, semi-structured, and lacking a predefined schema. The second thrust introduces a flexible join framework to handle complex join queries – including joins over spatial, temporal, and textual data – to allow multiple datasets to be combined to increase their value. The third thrust, since big low-value often involves sequences of events, focuses on efficient window query processing; parallel processing of window queries, in order to scale, is essential for big low-value data analytics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project supported basic research on technology for high-value analytics on what we refer to as big low-value data. In a data-driven world, there is a tremendously large amount of data produced by various sources including sensors, connected devices, and social media applications. While the amount of data is huge, the individual value of each data record is very low, e.g., a single sensor reading. The true value of this data can only be achieved by analyzing it in aggregate. Such analysis calls for novel storage and processing techniques such as the techniques that this project has developed. Traditional database management systems work primarily with tabular, flat data, with little or no support for the nested data that is now widely available. In contrast, modern big-data analytics systems, e.g., Spark, often employ an abundance of memory resources to load and process such data efficiently. Given the low-value nature of such data, it is not cost effective to load it all into memory since only in aggregate does the data become valuable.

To address high-value analytics on big low-value data (BLVD), this project explored three research thrusts. The first thrust focused on efficient storage and resource-aware query processing for large volumes of data that are nested, semistructured, and lacking a predefined schema. The second thrust introduced a flexible join framework to handle complex join queries – including joins over spatial, temporal, and textual data – to allow multiple datasets to be combined to increase their value. The third thrust, since big low-value data will often involve sequences of events, focused on efficient window query processing. Parallel processing of such queries, in order to scale, is essential for big low-value data analytics. The majority of the project work has been, or will be, integrated into the open-source Apache AsterixDB system so that it is readily available to other researchers and developers.

By developing improved techniques for analyzing big low-value data, this project's results should help data analysts address the information explosion coming from social media, the mobile web, and IoT. This in turn has the potential to benefit the broader public by providing a general-purpose foundation for gleaning high-value insights from high-volume, low-value data in domains such as public safety and public health. Results from the project have been freely shared with the community, both via publications and via open-source software at the Apache Software Foundation. The techniques developed within the project are general-purpose and can directly benefit other big data efforts. The results have seen industrial uptake at Couchbase, Inc., most recently in their new Capella Columnar DBaaS cloud offering. The project has also helped in educating students, at our universities and elsewhere, about data management and analysis technologies. Work on this project has provided an invaluable training opportunity for the students who have worked on it, with project alumni now working at leading big data vendors and teaching the next generation of big data students in academia.


Last Modified: 01/08/2025
Modified by: Michael J Carey
